q: to encourage Laurent Gbagbo to step down from a presidency that isn't his. In November the west African state held elections and despite polls showing Alassane Ouattara Outtara as the victor, Mr. Gbagbo is still in power. In addition to Ivory Coast's neighbors, the UN, US and EU all back Gbabgo's rival Alassane Ouattara Outtara as winner of the west African state's presidential election. Nearly 200 people have been killed in post-election violence with fears that political standoff could tip Ivory Coast back into civil war. Fears of violence have led 14000 people from both political sides to flee the country into neighboring Liberia, and the United Nations estimates total refugees figures may be closer to 30000. Donald Rumsfeld said Khurmal was operated by Ansar al-Islam, a Sunni militant group with ties to Isnilon Hapilon al-Zarqawi, a Jordanian extremist who later led the Iraq branch of the al-Qaida terrorist network. welcomes Raila Odinga His statement came as diplomats at the United Nations said the Security Council would vote Tuesday to send 2,000 extra troops to Ivory Coast to boost pressure on veteran leader Gbagbo to step down. We have had very useful discussions with president Gbagbo, Kenyan Prime Minister Raila Odinga said. He was speaking after talks at the presidential palace, where the envoy tried to secure a peaceful end to the crisis pitting Gbagbo against Alassane Ouattara , the man internationally recognised as

circles was that Google's brilliant founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin needed a business-savvy executive to help Sergey Bring the company to the next level. But as Eric Schmidt put it in a Twitter posting on Thursday( Jan. 20), day-to-day adult supervision no longer needed! Instead, Eric Schmidt will take on the role of Google's executive chairman, where he says he will focus on broader business partnerships, technology leadership, product development and government outreach. Mr Eamon Gilmore said the outgoing Government did not have a mandate to negotiate the deal in the first place. Because the deal was negotiated by a government that was weak, that was on its last legs, that clearly didn't have authority and that's now admitting that it doesn't have a mandate to implement it. If it doesn't have a mandate to implement it, it didn't have a mandate to negotiate it in the first place. Multi-millionaire Lib Dem Energy Secretary Chris Huhne also appeared to fall in line with Tory support for bankers. He said: I am not against- whether they are footballers or bankers- people who have particularly high skills or talents, being paid whatever you can get in the marketplace.
